It's a casual game, a rail shooter, mowing down neverending hordes of bad guys until your own inevitable demise. A generation ago, this would have been a coin-op game. No, it does not have overly sophisticated graphics or anything; it just delivers on its premise, offering a few minutes of pure mayhem when you have a half hour of downtime to spare.  The only thing everyone obsesses on is the fact that the enemies are IS (aka ISIS or Daesh). I do not understand why this is controversial. If this same game had Nazis as enemies instead, it would have had zero controversy. Hundreds of games (and movies) feature Nazis as convenient, easily disposed of cannonfodder that the heroes may slaughter without guilt. Why is it different with IS, when these guys are equally as irredeemablly evil as the Waffen SS? You are tasked with holding off the worst of the worst of the worst that humanity currently has to offer. There is literally no force on earth more evil than ISIS at this time, is there? What is the controversy?

IS Defense is essentially perfect. An old-school pure arcade shooter, it feels like it should have the big plastic machine-gun hanging off the front. Marvellous stuff - a genuine breath of fresh air, When so many games are vast boredom simulators, this is the quintessence of video games, distilled to utter purity.   Thank you.

IS Defence: ~~~~~~~~~  The year is 2020. North Africa is now under the control of IS, who is gathering a large army to launch the invasion of Europe via the Mediterranean Sea. NATO headquarters knows the exact locations of the launch, and is in need of courageous soldiers to stand against the invader until the end! Soldier, it is time to fight for the free world! Sign here to enrol!  IS Defence is an action / rail shooter game where you take control of a NATO soldier who is stationed on a vantage point with his machine gun, and you have to kill as many invaders as possible until your glorious death. This game has three maps available to you: The Sicilians Shores, The Spanish Harbour and The Croatian Mainland. You will have to beat the first map to unlock the second, and the second map to unlock the third. To do so you will have to eliminate a specific number of terrorists and vehicles.   At the start of a game, you will be stationary with your machine-gun, a rocket launcher and a certain amount of ammunition. You will notice two gauges on your screen; on the left is the support gauge and on the right your health gauge. Each time you eliminate an enemy (soldier or vehicle) you will see the left gauge going up and each time you pass a certain level, you will be able to call on your support team for assistance, which includes: supplies, infantry, artillery, airstrikes and helicopters. On the other hand, each time you get shot, or a suicidal enemy soldier manages to blow himself up at your vantage point, your right gauge will decrease really quickly until you see a black screen, which will mean that it’s game over! Also, you will acquire skill points in each map and use them to either upgrade yourself, your machine gun, your rocket launcher or your support calls. I really like the progressive difficulty throughout each map of the game. You will find that the first couple of waves will be nice and simple to eliminate, but then you will need to know the right support combination to stay alive as long as you can. It will become a fast and furious game, and you will have plenty of fun.   Graphically the game looks good, with great explosions here, there and everywhere. Good sound effects, too! In my opinion, however, the soldier’s animations could have been better.   It is a short game - you will probably unlock the other 2 maps within 3.5 hours but you will surely come back to it over and over. It is a fun game.   Positives: ~~~~~~~   - Good graphics - Good skills tree - Fast, fun and addictive gameplay - Achievements and trading cards  Negatives: ~~~~~~~~   - Only 3 maps available - Soldiers animation could have been better  IS Defence is a fun and fast rail shooter, it will keep you shooting for hours!  8/10  Key provided by developer/publisher for review purposes. Yes. Yes. And a million times: YES!  Delivered by the developers of the probably most controversial game 'Hatred' comes their newest work: IS Defense. So what is it about? In case you haven't noticed already, the game is set in a unreal (yet scaringly possible) future where ISIS has taken over north Africa and is starting an offensive against Europe. Your job is to stop them, one Bullet at a time...  (TL;DR in the end)  First things first, I don't like rail shooters. I don't like them at all. But this game does not feel like a rail shooter, more like a first-person tower defense, and it's totally AWESOME!   PLOT:  Your only task in the game is to pop some Jihadists. How? It's up to you. Unlike other railshooters (even though I won't count IS Defense as one) you don't just click with your cursor across the screen, instead you're placed on a stationary fortificated hill with a Machine gun (unlimited ammo, but magazine size of 200 shots) and a Bazooka (you start with 6 shots, you get more via supply drops, I'll get to them later), which can turn around 360 degrees.  Along with your weapons, you are given a variety of point streaks (Supply drop, Infantry support, Artillery support, Air support and Helicopter support). They are all feeding from the same score pool, that means if you call in a support, you will maybe not be able to call in a different one.  While you're mowing down the islamist invaders, you gain XP, which gives your character level ups. At each level up you get one point, which can be spent in your skill tree (4 branches: Player, Machine gun, Rockets, support), which works like most other skill trees (get the lower skills to unlock higher ones, the higher ones cost more points).   MAPS:  The game is really hard in the beginning, but the more games you play, the stronger your character gets, the easier the game gets. Then you unlock the next map, which is harder and requires you to rank up higher to beat it etc. I've only played the first 2 maps yet and I have to say that the developers did great work with them. I was expecting the maps to be the same with just a different look, but they aren't. While the first map is an open beach, the second map is a harbor. Where the first map was feeling hard first because of the wide field the enemies were approaching from, you will miss this wide open field in the second map. The enemies rush out of several buildings, stand on the roofs and rush around the corner with their armored cars (yes, they don't just have Toyotas with Machine guns).   ENEMIES:  The enemies vary from regular infantry, infantry with rocket launchers, suicide bombers, Toyotas and armored cars (at least I have seen so far) Watch out for the suicide bombers tho. They're easy to spot (red clothing, suicide belt and running directly at you without a gun continously shouting in Arabic) as long as all is chilled, but when the whole screen is full of enemies, you suddenly see a Kebab infront of your face and the game is over. Regular infantry will also throw grenades when they come close to you and run away when they're on fire. The enemy vehicles try to (and WILL) run over your infantry, watch out for them. When you shoot the driver of a Toyota while the car is in motion, the car will go loose, may run over people, crash into a building, drive into the ocean and die or just turn in circles until it explodes from the fire. All in all, the AI is perfect.   POINT STREAKS:   Supply drops: A dropship will drop a crate with either health or rockets into the combat zone. Shoot the crate to get it. Upgrades increase the crate number or the contents itself (like 100% health regen). My suggestion: stockpile your crates so you can shoot the health boxes when you need them instead of calling a drop when you're low at health and die.  Infantry support: My favourite one so far. This steak calls in a group of friendly soldiers (marked with a blue diamond) to fight the enemies. Not only do they help you get more kills, they also distract the enimes from you, giving you more time to fight more enemies, reload, etc. My suggestion: Use as much as possible.  Artillery support: Covers the combat zone with Artillery. Impacts are random and they might (and WILL) hit your allies too. Also the standard one is really short. My suggestion: Upgrade to the longer lasting artillery and when you use it, call in the infantry after the shelling is over.  Air support: Call in jets that nuke (not really) the combat zone. More effective but more expensive than artillery. My suggestion: Use it when you can affort it.  Helicopter support: Calls in an attack helicopter that attacks anything hostile on the combat zone. Destroys Toyotas in the blink of a second and really takes some weight off your shoulders. My suggestion: Use it when there's heavy enemy activity.   GRAPHICS/AMBIENT  The graphics are great, as you would expect it from a 2016 game. The game is running great on High-Ultra settings for me, only having massive lags sometimes when ♥♥♥♥ hits the fan but it only lasts a short moment and continues fluently afterwards. The explosions are realistic, shells are flying across the screen, blood, gore and corpses everywhere (you can set the body count in the options, I suggest 'unlimited' for the ultimae Kebab removal experience. The vehicles behave very realistic (like stated in the 'enemies' section). The game is really packing and you wil feel the adrenaline rush through your body while you're defending Europe from the terrorist invaders.   MODS  I tested no mods so far because the mod support just came in, but I expect some great stuff from you guys.   TL;DR This is the ultimate fast-paced first-person kebab remover game in the world. Get it. GET IT NOW!

tl;dr at the end  Destructive Creations are the guys behind Hatred. They got some hate because of it's controversy. You were literally butchering everyone around you. Now, tell me, would any other studio dare to touch such a topic and make a game out of it? No? Well, Destructive Creations did, and I love them for it.  But we are here to talk about IS Defense, not Hatred. So let's start. What is IS Defense? It's a game set in fictional year 2020. ISIS became so powerful their expansion got out of hand. You are playing as a NATO MG operator and your mission is to defend different positions/shores of Europe.  Is it any good? Yes, it is.  Let's start with the price. 6,99€, £5.50, $7.99. Is it worth the price? YES! Come on, it's cheap, and it's good. Graphics. This game is using Unreal Engine 4. Does it look good? Well, you guessed it, yes! How does it work? Pretty good. Even on my old GTX 550 Ti it runs well. Gameplay. It's a on-rails shooter. You can't move, but you can rotate your turret, so the enemies are coming from every side, 360 degrees action. Sound design is pretty nice as well. The sounds are well-made. You also have upgrades which you unlock by killing enemies. They are really important and without them you probably won't win. The only problem with this game is, in my opinion, the AI. You can call in reinforcements and sometimes they will literally stand in front of you and block your view. Same with the enemies. They will just stand there like ♥♥♥♥ing idiots.  So basically, this game is very, very good. Especially for it's price. Like literally, you get around 15 hours of fun (at least that's how much i'll be expecting when i finish the game) and it's cheap as hell.  People may hate this game because you are killing MUSLIMS, and will call you a racist, but what they don't understand is that when they say that, THEY are the racists, not you. IS members are not only Muslims. Get your facts straight before saying something like this. So, people that call everyone that likes this game racist, please kill yourselves, because you are racists, not us.  That's it.  tl;dr Solid on-rails shooter with upgrade system for your character, your gun and special 'skills'. Cheap and worth it. Lasts for 10-15 hours. NATO against IS (Islamic State aka terrorists).

IS Defense,  As the name says, puts you in a defensive position behind a fictional LMG. The objective of the game is as simple as it can be entertaining. Hold your ground as long as possible. This game is very similar to P.O.W., Operation Wolf, Vietnam Gunner, Beach Head etc. The genre is as old as computer gaming and it hasn't lost its glory. That is, if you like those kind of games.  So what is there actually to do? 1) Take out as many targets as possible before dying. 2) By destroying targets you gain round based and persistent experience points. 3) Persistent Experience points can be used to acquire permanent upgrades. 4) Round based experience points are used to call in power ups, or allied aid through soldiers, planes, arty and helicopters.  The presentation is more than adequate. The Sound effects and narration are good.  Final verdict: If you're offended by the name of this game then you shouldn't be on Steam, which is a western product, in the first place. Besides of that, IS Defense is a stationary turret defense action packed ride that delivers for its low price.

It's okay for the cost. Worth more than a similarly priced fast food combo meal.   It's a simple yet challenging static defense game, which plays like it belongs in an old school arcade. No, it's not a rail shooter. This train ain't going anywhere unfortunately.  Pros:  Kill Islamic State. 'nuff said.  Pretty graphics, lots of fire and explosions. The smoke, mist, and vegetation obscuring the battlefield give it a realistic feel that makes you question if the daeshbags are coming. (get UAV skill to end this problem)  Gets challenging and strategic. You have to deal with flanking attacks, and balance your supply, infantry, artillery, airstrike, and chopper support. Decisions have to be made very quickly.  The real time leaders board that updates as you play. Good call.  ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~  Cons:  Too short. There's only three levels.   AI is stooopid, even considering that they're daeshbags. Drivers will run over their own infantry, and crash into things. Vehicles don't move intelligently, they seem to just follow a set path and smash through anything in the way. Enemy and friendly infantry make no use of cover and concealment or even keeping one's head down.  There's only a few enemy types I've seen so far. Infantry, suicide bombers, trucks, humvees, and the three different landing boats. When you play your first game you'll see all of them. Nothing new to see through game progression except the two other maps.  Debris piles up and clutters the battlefield pretty badly. This is a good feature sometimes, but annoying when an enemy truck parks behind a pile of blown up vehicles and can't be hit. Also messes with enemy vehicle pathing. It looks silly when infantry are standing on top of a wrecked truck engulfed in flames and don't even notice.  ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~  Wishlist:  More maps.  More enemy types. Tanks, rocketeers, car bombs, armored personnel carriers, etc. Make advanced infantry that throw grenades if they get too close.   Make it an actual rail shooter. Do convoy security. Have to protect the friendly vehicles in the convoy until they get to their destination. You could string along the missions and incorporate a light storyline instead of making them all a fight to the death. Ideally this entire game would be just an added survival mode feature while a campaign mode made the bulk of the game.  I hope you incorporate such into sequels/expansions.

Five problematics out of five.  Deus Vult!  In all seriousness, this is a surprisingly polished game. There isn't a lot to it, structure-wise: you have three levels and four skill trees, and you use a machine gun, rocket launcher, and five different support abilities to destroy waves of attacking soldiers and vehicles. It's very reminiscent of classic arcade games, both in its structure and in its difficulty.  Its simplicity works in its favor, given how the game progresses. You aren't just completing a stage by defeating X waves of enemies and moving on to the next; your objective is to last as long as possible against an increasingly intense assault, with your eventual score ranked according to both your number of kills and the length of time you spent alive. At the beginning of the game, you're going to die early and often, but as you play, you rack up skill points which you can invest into persistent upgrades across attempts.  As you unlock increasingly powerful abilities, you find yourself able to last just a little bit longer each time, and there's a real element of challenge involved in learning how and when to use your support abilities as well as what to prioritize and when. The real challenge of the game is not to finish all three maps (which will happen pretty much no matter what, as 'finishing' a map is as simple as racking up a certain number of kills across your playthroughs), but to push yourself to see how long you can last. And you will eventually lose: like the recently released Devil Daggers, 'winning' just means getting further than anyone else before you bite it.  My main criticism is a lack of enemy variety: there are normal old soldiers, suicide bombers, technicals, humvees, and three types of landing craft (pontoons, and small and large troop carriers). I'd have liked to see more, different types of soldiers (engineers, grenadiers, machinegunners) or enemy air units. But for the price, and the amount of visual spectacle going on, this is an easy recommendation for a few hours of relaxing rat-a-tat.
